title: Security Assessment
description: Assessing security controls and managing system security plans

questions.question: Do you periodically assess your security controls?
questions.context: Regular assessment ensures security controls are working as intended.
questions.examples: Annual assessments, control testing, self-assessments, third-party assessments
questions.followUp: How often do you assess controls? Who does it? What's the scope?
questions.discussion: Security control assessments determine if controls are implemented correctly, operating as intended, and producing desired outcomes.

questions.question: Do you develop and update plans of action for deficiencies?
questions.context: When assessments find problems, you need plans to fix them with timelines.
questions.examples: POA&M, remediation plans, milestone tracking, corrective action plans
questions.followUp: How do you track deficiencies? What's in your POA&M? How are milestones managed?
questions.discussion: Plans of action and milestones (POA&Ms) document planned remediation actions for identified weaknesses and track progress.

questions.question: Do you monitor security controls continuously?
questions.context: Continuous monitoring ensures controls remain effective between formal assessments.
questions.examples: Ongoing monitoring, automated tools, dashboards, metrics collection
questions.followUp: What do you monitor continuously? What tools are used? Who reviews results?
questions.discussion: Continuous monitoring maintains ongoing awareness of security posture and control effectiveness to support risk management decisions.

questions.question: Do you maintain system security plans?
questions.context: SSPs document how security requirements are implemented in your systems.
questions.examples: System Security Plan, security documentation, control descriptions, system boundaries
questions.followUp: Do you have an SSP? When was it last updated? Does it cover all systems with CUI?
questions.discussion: System security plans describe system boundaries, environments, security requirements implementation, and connections to other systems.
